facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave from an order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna setting aside an order of acquittal of the appellants by the Sessions Judge, Purnea, and directing their retrial.

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, J. This is an appeal by special leave from an order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna setting aside an order of acquittal of the appellants by the Sessions Judge, Purnea, and directing their retrial.

facts.text: The appellants were prosecuted for alleged offences under sections 147, 148, 323, 324, 326, 302 and 302/149 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were prosecuted for alleged offences under sections 147, 148, 323, 324, 326, 302 and 302/149 of the Indian Penal Code at the instance of one Polai Lal Biswas who lodged a companyplaint against them before the police.

facts.text: Polai Lal Biswas lodged a complaint against the appellants before the police.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were prosecuted for alleged offences under sections 147, 148, 323, 324, 326, 302 and 302/149 of the Indian Penal Code at the instance of one Polai Lal Biswas who lodged a companyplaint against them before the police.

facts.text: While the complainant was harvesting the paddy crop on his field at about 10 a.m. on 29th November, 1949, a mob of about fifty persons came on to the field armed with ballams, lathis and other weapons.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that, while the companyplainant was harvesting the paddy crop on his field at about 10 a.m. on 29th November, 1949, a mob of about fifty persons came on to the field armed with ballams, lathis and other weapons and that the first appellant Logendranath Jha, who was leading the mob, demanded a settlement of all outstanding disputes with the companyplainant and said he would number allow the paddy to be removed unless the disputes were settled.

facts.text: First appellant Logendranath Jha was leading the mob.

anchor.surface_text: a mob of about fifty persons came on to the field armed with ballams, lathis and other weapons and that the first appellant Logendranath Jha, who was leading the mob, demanded a settlement of all outstanding disputes with the companyplainant and said he would number allow the paddy to be removed unless the disputes were settled.

facts.text: Logendranath Jha demanded a settlement of all outstanding disputes with the complainant and said he would not allow the paddy to be removed unless the disputes were settled.

anchor.surface_text: and that the first appellant Logendranath Jha, who was leading the mob, demanded a settlement of all outstanding disputes with the companyplainant and said he would number allow the paddy to be removed unless the disputes were settled. An altercation followed as a result of which Logendra ordered an assault by his men.

facts.text: Logendra and one of his men, Harihar, gave ballam blows to one of the labourers, Kangali, who fell down and died on the spot.

anchor.surface_text: An altercation followed as a result of which Logendra ordered an assault by his men. Then Logendra and one of his men, Harihar, gave ballam blows to one of the abourers, Kangali, who fell down and died on the spot. Information was given to the police who investigated the case and submitted the charge-sheet.

facts.text: Information was given to the police who investigated the case and submitted the charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: Then Logendra and one of his men, Harihar, gave ballam blows to one of the abourers, Kangali, who fell down and died on the spot. Information was given to the police who investigated the case and submitted the charge-sheet.

facts.text: The committing Magistrate found that a prima facie case was made out and committed the appellants to the Court of Sessions for trial.

anchor.surface_text: Information was given to the police who investigated the case and submitted the charge-sheet. The companymitting Magistrate found that a prima facie case was made out and companymitted the appellants to the Court of Sessions for trial.

facts.text: Appellants pleaded not guilty alleging that Mohender and Debender, brothers of Logendra and appellants 2 and 3, were not present in the village of Dandkhora with which they had no concern, as all lands there allotted to Logendra at previous partition.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants pleaded number guilty alleging inter alia, that Mohender and Debender, the brothers of Logendra  appellants 2 and 3  were number present in the village of Dandkhora with which they had numberconcern, as all the lands in that village had been allotted to Logendra at a previous partition, that Logendra himself was number in the village at the time of the occurrence but arrived soon after.

facts.text: Logendra was not in the village at the time of the occurrence but arrived soon after and was dragged to the place at the instance of his enemies and placed under arrest by the Assistant Sub-Inspector of Police.

anchor.surface_text: that Logendra himself was number in the village at the time of the occurrence but arrived soon after and was dragged to the place at the instance of his enemies in the village and was placed under arrest by the Assistant Sub-Inspector of Police who had arrived there previously.

facts.text: There were two factions in the village, one led by Harimohan, a relation of the complainant, and the other by Logendra, with numerous revenue and criminal proceedings and long-standing enmity between the families.

anchor.surface_text: It was also alleged that there were two factions in the village, one of which was led by one Harimohan, a relation of the companyplainant, and the other by Logendra and there had been numerous revenue and criminal proceedings and long-standing enemity between the families of these leaders as a result of which this false case was foisted upon the appellants.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found that the existence of factions as alleged by the appellants was true.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge examined the evidence in great detail and found that the existence of factions as alleged by the appellants was true.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found that the appellants' plea of alibi was not satisfactorily made out.

anchor.surface_text: He found, however, that the appellants plea of alibi was number satisfactorily made out, but the truth of the prosecution, he proceeded to observe, cannot be judged by the falsehood of the defence number can the prosecution derive its strength from the weakness of the defence.

facts.text: Sessions Judge disbelieved the prosecution story that Polai had batai settlement of the disputed land and raised the paddy crop which he was harvesting.

anchor.surface_text: Approaching the case in this manner and seeing that the basis of the prosecution case was that Polai had batai settlement of the disputed land and had raised the paddy crop which he was harvesting when the occurrence took place, the learned Sessions Judge examined the evidence of the prosecution witnesses who belonged to the opposite faction critically and found that the story of the prosecution was number acceptable.

facts.text: Polai was 19 years old, unmarried, living with his maternal grandmother Parasmani who brought him up from childhood.

anchor.surface_text: Polai, who was alleged to have taken the land on batai settlement from his own maternal grandmother Parasmani who brought him up from his childhood, was only 19 years old and unmarried and was still living with his grandmother.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted the appellants of all charges.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge accordingly acquitted the appellants of all the charges framed against them.

facts.text: Complainant Polai preferred a revision petition to the High Court under section 439 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the companyplainant Polai preferred a revision petition to the High Court under section 439 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: High Court set aside the Sessions Judge's order of acquittal as perverse and directed retrial.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who heard the petition reviewed the evidence at some length and came to the companyclusion that the judgment of the learned Sessions Judge companyld number be allowed to stand as the acquittal of the appellants was perverse.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that High Court exceeded its powers in revision by re-appraising evidence and reversing findings of fact.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judge in the High Court did number properly appreciate the scope of inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal. Though sub-section  1  of section 439 authorises the High Court to exercise, in its discretion, any of the powers companyferred on a companyrt of appeal by section 423, sub-section  4  specifically excludes the power to companyvert a finding of acquittal into one of companyviction.

facts.text: High Court directed re-trial without convicting but expressed strong views influencing the retrial.

anchor.surface_text: No Doubt, the learned Judge formally companyplied with sub-section  4  by directing only a re-trial of the appellants without companyvicting them, and warned that the companyrts retrying the case should number be influenced by any expression of opinion companytained in his judgment. But there can be little doubt that he loaded the dice against the appellants.

facts.text: Sessions Judge found a number of discrepancies and contradictions in prosecution evidence and concealment of real facts.

anchor.surface_text: He also found a number of discrepancies and companytradictions in the evidence of the prosecution witnesses, which, in his view, tended to show that the prosecution was guilty of companycealment of the real facts.

facts.text: Sessions Judge concluded it is not possible to apportion liability or decide which party commenced the fight.

anchor.surface_text: In view of such companycealment of real facts, the learned Judge companycluded, it does number appear to me to be possible to apportion liability and to decide which of the two parties companymenced the fight and which acted in self-defence.

This is an appeal by special leave from an order of the High Court of Judicature at Patna setting aside an order of acquittal of the appellants by the Sessions Judge, Purnea, and directing their retrial.

The appellants were prosecuted for alleged offences under sections 147, 148, 323, 324, 326, 302 and 302/149 of the Indian Penal Code at the instance of one Polai Lal Biswas who lodged a complaint against them before the police.

issues.text: Whether a revision petition under section 439 CrPC by a private party against an order of acquittal is incompetent having regard to section 417 CrPC which permits appeal against acquittal only at the instance of the Government?

anchor.surface_text: having regard to section 417 of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides for an appeal to the High Court from an order of acquittal only at the instance of the Government, a revision petition under section 439 at the instance of a private party was incompetent

issues.text: Whether the High Court properly appreciated the scope of its inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal under section 439 CrPC and whether it exceeded its powers by re-appraising evidence, characterising findings as perverse, reversing factual findings, and directing retrial?

holdings.text: We think it is unnecessary to express any opinion on the first contention of Mr. Sinha especially as the respondent is unrepresented, as we are of opinion that his second and alternative contention must prevail.

anchor.surface_text: We think it is unnecessary to express any opinion on the first contention of Mr. Sinha especially as the respondent is unrepresented, as we are of opinion that his second and alternative contention must prevail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declined to decide due to respondent unrepresented and alternative ground sufficient.

holdings.text: the learned Judge in the High Court did not properly appreciate the scope of inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal. Though sub-section (1) of section 439 authorises the High Court to exercise, in its discretion, any of the powers conferred on a Court of appeal by section 423, sub-section (4) specifically excludes the power to convert a finding of acquittal into one of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judge in the High Court did not properly appreciate the scope of inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal. Though sub-section (1) of section 439 authorises the High Court to exercise, in its discretion, any of the powers conferred on a Court of appeal by section 423, sub-section (4) specifically excludes the power to convert a finding of acquittal into one of conviction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.439(1) granting appellate powers per s.423 but limited by s.439(4) prohibiting conversion of acquittal to conviction.

holdings.text: This does not mean that in dealing with a revision petition by a private party against an order of acquittal, the High Court could in the absence of any error on a point of law re-appraise the evidence and reverse the findings of facts on which the acquittal was based, provided only it stopped short of finding the accused guilty and passing sentence on him.

anchor.surface_text: This does not mean that in dealing with a revision petition by a private party against an order of acquittal, the High Court could in the absence of any error on a point of law re-appraise the evidence and reverse the findings of facts on which the acquittal was based, provided only it stopped short of finding

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court in private revision limited to correcting legal errors; cannot substitute views on facts even if stopping short of conviction.

holdings.text: By merely characterising the judgment of the trial Court as perverse and lacking in perspective, the High Court cannot reverse pure findings of fact based on the trial Courts appreciation of the evidence in the case.

anchor.surface_text: By merely characterising the judgment of the trial Court as perverse and lacking in perspective, the High Court cannot reverse pure findings of fact based on the trial Courts appreciation of the evidence in the case. holdings.reasoning_summary: Mere label of 'perverse' insufficient to reverse trial court's factual appreciation without legal error.

holdings.text: No doubt, the learned Judge formally complied with sub-section (4) by directing only a re-trial of the appellants without convicting them, and warned that the courts retrying the case should not be influenced by any expression of opinion contained in his judgment. But there can be little doubt that he loaded the dice against the appellants

anchor.surface_text: We think it is unnecessary to express any opinion on the first contention of Mr. Sinha especially as the respondent is unrepresented, as we are of opinion that his second and alternative contention must prevail.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the learned Judge in the High Court did not properly appreciate the scope of inquiry in revision against an order of acquittal. Though sub-section (1) of section 439 authorises the High Court to exercise, in its discretion, any of the powers conferred on a Court of appeal by section 423, sub-section (4) specifically excludes the power to convert a finding of acquittal into one of conviction.
